image.altText: Rupert Murdoch, an older man with glasses, reads newspapers in the back of a car.

props.synopsis: His son Lachlan Murdoch will become the sole chair of News Corp following his decision to step down.

title.children: 'The time is right': Rupert Murdoch steps down as chairman of Fox Corporation and News Corp

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall sit, surrounded by their children, all the women holding bouquets

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch always wanted his media empire to stay in the family, but he could never commit to an heir. Despite having six children, only three were ever considered viable successors.

title.children: 'It's like The Godfather': How Rupert Murdoch's children spent their lives in competition

image.altText: a woman in front of a sold sign out the front of an apartment block with a real estate agent

props.synopsis: Almost one in six sellers in Sydney's high-construction neighbourhoods are losing money, some as much as $100,000 for their lifetime investment, with interest rate squeeze pushing buyers to sell up for a loss.

title.children: Ella lost $100,000 when she sold her Sydney unit bought just five years ago — and she's not alone

image.altText: A ribbon bound version of Australia's constitution with a photo of the Australian outback in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia will vote on whether to make a change to its constitution next month. But what is this document? And what is the proposed change? We break it down for you here, and show you what the constitution would look like if the Voice referendum is passed.

title.children: Here's how the Australian Constitution would change if the Voice referendum is passed

image.altText: Zelenskyy standing with US senators.

props.synopsis: After seeking to shore up international support at the United Nations, Mr Zelenskyy comes to Washington on a crosstown blitz including meetings with military leaders and Mr Biden and an evening address at the National Archives museum.

title.children: Zelenskyy faces tough crowd in US with some Republicans rejecting push for $37 billion

image.altText: Imran Khan walks through a dense crowd of men as he tries to leave a courtroom while wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: As former Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan languishes in a jail cell near Islamabad and his supporters fall silent in fear, his family welcomed the ABC inside his heavily guarded home in Lahore.

title.children: Imran Khan was rich, famous and powerful. Now he’s in a tiny, filthy prison cell in Pakistan

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Politicians react to Rupert Murdoch stepping down, King Charles visits fire-damaged Notre-Dame Cathedral. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Planet Earth is about to receive a special delivery — the biggest sample yet from an asteroid. A NASA spacecraft will fly by Earth on Sunday and drop off what is expected to be at least a cupful of rubble it grabbed from the asteroid Bennu, closing out a seven-year quest. The sample capsule will parachute into the Utah desert, US, as its mothership, the Osiris-Rex spacecraft, zooms off for an encounter with another asteroid. Scientists anticipate getting about 250 grams of pebbles and dust, much more than the teaspoon or so brought back by Japan from two other asteroids. No other country has fetched pieces of asteroids. These preserved time capsules from the dawn of our solar system could help explain how Earth — and life — came to be. University of Arizona’s Dante Lauretta is the mission’s lead scientist. “I ask myself how many heart-pounding moments can you have in one lifetime because I feel like I might be hitting my limit,” she says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: An asteroid sample is about to land on Earth and it's the biggest one yet

children.content: The Osiris-Rex spacecraft will parachute the asteroid sample to Earth.
(AP Photo: NASA)
Planet Earth is about to receive a special delivery — the biggest sample yet from an asteroid.
A NASA spacecraft will fly by Earth on Sunday and drop off what is expected to be at least a cupful of rubble it grabbed from the asteroid Bennu, closing out a seven-year quest.
The sample capsule will parachute into the Utah desert, US, as its mothership, the Osiris-Rex spacecraft, zooms off for an encounter with another asteroid.
The sample will come from the asteroid Bennu.
(AP Photo: NASA)
Scientists anticipate getting about 250 grams of pebbles and dust, much more than the teaspoon or so brought back by Japan from two other asteroids.
No other country has fetched pieces of asteroids.
These preserved time capsules from the dawn of our solar system could help explain how Earth — and life — came to be.
University of Arizona’s Dante Lauretta is the mission’s lead scientist.
“I ask myself how many heart-pounding moments can you have in one lifetime because I feel like I might be hitting my limit,” she says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC The media world is reeling from the news Rupert Murdoch is retiring after decades building his empire, appointing his son Lachlan as sole chair of New Corp and head of Fox. He’s had remarkable business success, but also been criticised over episodes such as the UK phone-hacking scandal and Fox News’s role in promoting rigged-election conspiracies. Former prime ministers Kevin Rudd and Malcolm Turnbull are among those who’ve called for a Murdoch Royal Commission to investigate how News Corp wields its power in Australia. NPR journalist David Folkenflik, who wrote the book Murdoch’s World, says the retirement isn’t completely unexpected, given Rupert Murdoch’s age and the way he’s been grooming his son for several years. “One can understand why a 92-year-old billionaire might finally step away and leave things in the hands of his designated successor,” he told the ABC’s North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan. “But… it does take you aback – it's a moment to reflect, It's a moment to register all that he has done, his incredible successes, his extraordinary record and, you know, the wreckage he left in his wake as well.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rupert Murdoch's had 'incredible successes', but also leaves 'wreckage in his wake': author

children.content: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC
The media world is reeling from the news Rupert Murdoch is retiring after decades building his empire, appointing his son Lachlan as sole chair of New Corp and head of Fox.
He’s had remarkable business success, but also been criticised over episodes such as the
UK phone-hacking scandal
and
Fox News’s role in promoting rigged-election conspiracies
Former prime ministers Kevin Rudd and Malcolm Turnbull are among those who’ve called for a Murdoch Royal Commission to investigate how News Corp wields its power in Australia.

NPR journalist David Folkenflik, who wrote the book Murdoch’s World, says the retirement isn’t completely unexpected, given Rupert Murdoch’s age and the way he’s been grooming his son for several years.
“One can understand why a 92-year-old billionaire might finally step away and leave things in the hands of his designated successor,” he told the ABC’s North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan.

“But… it does take you aback – it's a moment to reflect, It's a moment to register all that he has done, his incredible successes, his extraordinary record and, you know, the wreckage he left in his wake as well.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's the second day of King Charles's state visit to France. He went from a meeting with young athletes in a working-class, multicultural suburb of Paris to an emotional stop in front of the fire-damaged Notre Dame Cathedral. Charles and Queen Camilla, accompanied by French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife, Brigitte, listened to a presentation about ongoing renovation work at Notre-Dame. The day before the king said he had been “utterly appalled by the scenes of such devastation following the catastrophic fire” in April 2019. Charles and Camilla weren't able to enter the cathedral for safety reasons, but French president Macron invited them to take a closer look at the entrance as dozens of workers on the higher floors of the monument applauded the king and took pictures. The cathedral is due to reopen at the end of next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: King Charles makes a stop at the fire-damaged Notre Dame Cathedral

children.content: (AP: Christophe Petit Tesson)
It's the second day of King Charles's state visit to France.
He went from a meeting with young athletes in a working-class, multicultural suburb of Paris to an emotional stop in front of the fire-damaged Notre Dame Cathedral.
Charles and Queen Camilla, accompanied by French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife, Brigitte, listened to a presentation about ongoing renovation work at Notre-Dame.
The day before the king said he had been “utterly appalled by the scenes of such devastation following the catastrophic fire” in April 2019.

Charles and Camilla weren't able to enter the cathedral for safety reasons, but French president Macron invited them to take a closer look at the entrance as dozens of workers on the higher floors of the monument applauded the king and took pictures.
The cathedral is due to reopen at the end of next year.

image.altText: An illustrated image of Norman Bates with half his face as an android

props.synopsis: Five years after researchers created a psychopathic algorithm to demonstrate bias and discrimination in artificial intelligence, we're still learning its lessons.

title.children: 'Norman still haunts me': Why warnings from the world's first 'psychopath AI' are as relevant as ever

image.altText: A photo of a woman laughing in a hospital bed with her son and daughter next to her

props.synopsis: The former nurse was diagnosed with an aggressive form of motor neurone disease and given months to live. Her dying wish was to save lives — and she did in an Australian first.

title.children: Marlene chose to end her life with dignity. But her death saved four others

image.altText: A child wears a facemask and steers a boat on the water with the red-orange sky behind them.

props.synopsis: For the first time in three years, Australians face the risk of significant bushfires. Are we any better prepared for big fires than we were before Black Summer?

title.children: El Niño has ramped up bushfire risks again, but Australia's in a better place now than before Black Summer

image.altText: A hover fly perched on a flower inside a greenhouse.

props.synopsis: As threats to Australia's bee population increase, including from varroa mite, a fly is emerging as a top alternative pollinator for crops.

title.children: If something happens to bees, it's hoped these flies can fill the role of pollinator

image.altText: Smoke covers a destroyed building

props.synopsis: At least two people are dead and 21 injured in Russia's largest attack on Ukraine since August.

title.children: Massive Russian missile attack starts fires, injures dozens in six Ukrainian cities

image.altText: A portrait of a man with blond hair and a beard, wearing a navy pullover and beanie.

props.synopsis: A proposed gold, lead, zinc and silver mine near Blayney in Central West NSW is a step closer to becoming a reality, but a nearby community says it is not being included in the conversation.

title.children: Mining exploration thought 'abandoned' by locals ramps up in Central West NSW

image.altText: A woman laughs in the middle of a clothing racks with a red sparkly dress in front.

props.synopsis: Volunteers transform a vacant shop in south-west Sydney into a formal wear outlet where students can choose from hundreds of items and it won't cost them a thing.

title.children: No price tags here: Cost of living no obstacle for kids needing glamorous dress or suit for school formal

image.altText: A black and white photo of an unseen woman holding up a hand to protect herself.

props.synopsis: The Supreme Court gives NSW Police extraordinary powers to recover and relocate an at-risk teenager by flying her to a safe house in Sydney.

title.children: Police considered the risk of harm to 16yo 'Emma' so great, they asked to charter a plane to rescue her

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks at a podium at the National Press Club

props.synopsis: No campaigner Jacinta Nampijinpa Price told the National Press Club last week there are no ongoing negative impacts of colonisation on Indigenous Australians. RMIT ABC Fact Check takes a look.

title.children: We fact checked Jacinta Nampijinpa Price on the negative impacts of colonisation. Here's what we found

image.altText: Wind farms at dusk with the sun setting behind them on the coast line

props.synopsis: The debate still rages about dealing with climate change and, close to home, Australia's energy transition, which is under way but accompanied by increasing pain and problems, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Albanese government faces an uphill road and angry locals as it drives change to renewables

image.altText: An aerial image of a power station with white towers and steam, against a blue-pink horizon.

props.synopsis: A high-stakes fight over the future of a failed Australian coal mine descends into acrimony, as a major power station takes legal action against consultancy Deloitte.

title.children: Power fight turns nasty as US-controlled plant decries efforts to 'destroy' its rights

image.altText: Matildas players celebrate winning penalty against France.

props.synopsis: Australia has more public statues of animals than women, but there is hope the "brass ceiling" will be smashed this year with the raising of four statues of women in capital cities, and at least eight more planned.

title.children: Women are woefully under-represented among public statues across Australia, but the tide is turning

image.altText: Generic photo of Qld firefighter standing blurred surrounded by flames in a bushfire in Qld

props.synopsis: In what could be the worst fire season since Black Summer, authorities are concerned about lingering "complacency" in suburban areas of the state and among tourists.

title.children: Why everybody needs to be prepared for bushfires – even if you live in suburbia

image.altText: A coach speaks to Melbourne AFL players during a 2023 premiership match.

props.synopsis: Richmond opts for one of the most experienced assistants in the AFL as it finally fills the role vacated by three-time premiership coach Damien Hardwick.

title.children: 'A great fit for the club': Tigers throw support behind Hardwick's long-term successor

image.altText: A Collingwood AFL player pumps his fists as he celebrates a goal.

props.synopsis: After being sidelined with injury since early August, Nick Daicos is included in Collingwood's line-up for the grand final qualifier, as GWS prepares to contain the young Magpies star.

title.children: Giants aim to 'minimise the damage' as Daicos makes Magpies return in preliminary final

image.altText: A heavily tattooed man sitting in a car, taking a selfie.

props.synopsis: Stanley Turvey had been a fugitive for hours when he crossed paths with an unwitting Melbourne man having a drink at a caravan park. As the investigation into his shooting death begins, here's a look at how the manhunt unfolded.

title.children: 'What are you doing mate?' Stranger reveals he shared a 'quiet beer' with man on the run

image.altText: Julie Bishop speaks to the media

props.synopsis: A 24-year-old man is remanded in custody, charged with attempted murder and assault. The ANU says it was not given relevant information before the violent incident.

title.children: 'I was so angry': ANU chancellor Julie Bishop says university was in the dark ahead of stabbings

image.altText: Australian surfer Owen Wright covers his face as he is overcome by emotion after winning the Tahitit Pro while wearing a safety

props.synopsis: High-profile head injuries are forcing surfers to rethink the decades-old stigma around wearing helmets, particularly when taking on death-defying waves.

title.children: Surfing is one of the only extreme sports where helmets are rarely worn — but that's starting to change

image.altText: A young man in an orange cap, at night, talking to media, with reflective light obscuring his face.

props.synopsis: Oscar Piastri is 11th in the drivers' championship, with six top 10 finishes and a best of fourth at the British Grand Prix.

title.children: Armed with upgrades and a new contract, Piastri sets sights on Japan

image.altText: An elderly, bespectacled woman stands near a street in a country town.

props.synopsis: A senate inquiry into regional bank closures hears of the dramatic impact on elderly people and those who cannot travel easily.

title.children: Regional bank closures 'ripping the heart out of country towns', inquiry told

image.altText: Old newspaper articles

props.synopsis: The deadline for the final report into unsolved deaths suspected of being LGBTIQ hate crimes in NSW has been extended after police delayed providing crucial documents.

title.children: NSW Police need 900 years to clear backlog of unsolved homicides, gay hate inquiry told

image.altText: Justin Trudeau shaking hands with Narendra Modi.

props.synopsis: The move comes after India warned nationals in Canada to exercise "caution" as ties between the two nations deteriorate.

title.children: India suspends visa services in Canada as tensions flare over killing of Sikh independence activist

image.altText: brahman

props.synopsis: It's three times more likely than foot-and-mouth disease, but Australia still has no vaccine bank for lumpy skin disease.

title.children: With the threat of lumpy skin disease looming, where is Australia's access to vaccines?

image.altText: A close-up of a cage on the back of a police paddywagon.

props.synopsis: The Indigenous boy, who authorities have confirmed had done nothing wrong, was dragged kicking and screaming from a house and placed into the cage of the vehicle by police officers.

title.children: Inquiries triggered after 'distressed' 11-year-old placed into police paddy wagon in the NT

image.altText: An Indonesian woman crying with her hand at her face.

props.synopsis: In the latest series of cases involving blasphemy laws in Indonesia, a TikToker with more than than 2 million followers is found guilty and jailed for two years for saying an Islamic phrase before eating crispy pork skin.

title.children: Woman jailed for two years and fined $25,000 for eating pork on TikTok in Indonesia

image.altText: A woman on a train films herself

props.synopsis: A few weeks ago Sabrina Bahsoon could travel on London's public transport system without being noticed, but in just a few short weeks she's become "Tube Girl", whose self-shot dancing videos on her commute have sparked a viral social media trend.

title.children: Who is 'Tube Girl'? How a viral sensation is sparking conversations about self-confidence
